p.s: The novel Gun Love written by Jennifer Clement and published in year 2019 deals with the story of Pearl and her mother Margot who live in negative conditions in a car at the trailer park.
When Pearl came to the foster family after her mother's death she met Helen.
In the following text, I will point out Helen's problem by analysing her character as represented by the narrator (Pearl) in this part of the novel.
First of all, Helen is eight years old and is very small (ll. 1f.).

Due to the description of Pearl about Helen's height from the window even smaller standing beside me (l. 1) shows that she looks from the window small but in reality she is even smaller which also underlines that she is really very small.
You can assume that Helen looks about five although she is eight years old because of her small height.
The character is described childish as she is still a little child.
Helen smells also like burned marshmallows (l. 3) which Pearl describes as well (l. 3).
So you can conclude that Helen smells well which is also a symbol of being hygienic and the opposite of dirty.
The fact that she talks nonstop (l. 5) intends to convey the impression that she wants to talk all the time.
That could be dependent on her situation as a foster child because she does not have a relationship to her family so she is no one who supports her and listens to hearher when she needed.
Due to this behaviour her loneliness and sadness get very obvious.
Helen is afraid that they could leave her too as all her foster families did.
The fact that she had too many foster families becomes clear in lines 11f too many homes, too many people, too many changes.

This is also underlined by the fact that she had no idea who she was or where she came from (ll. 5f.) because for a child like Helen it was very hard to change everything many times and get used to it quickly.
Because of this she is mistrust.

The character finds herself in an inner conflict which gets especially obvious when she says that she has two mommysmommies, 10 brothers and 11 sisters, two twin sisters, a twin brother, lived near a park and near a beach, born in a hospital and at home and that she is many ethnicities (ll. 6ff.).
She is confused and insecure.
She does not know what is right and what is wrong.
She makes all the people who she met in heirher foster families to her family which shows that she really wants to have a family but she is not able to realize that they are not her family.
On the other hand it shows her loyalityloyalty true-blue (l. 11) and that she never forgets anyone.

Due to her description of her life at her foster families you can conclude that she lived in bad and negative conditions there because they gave her only cereal to eat (l. 14), one square of toilet paper a day (l. 15), slept on the floor and had to reuse dental floss and tea bags (l. 15).
They did not care of her and offered her a terrible life.
For that reason she is afraid and has psychological problems which is for example underlined in the way how she speaks.
She speeksspeaks to herself in the third person (l. 17).
She can notcannot realize that she exists and who she was (l. 6).
She could not develop an identity.
Helen also dreams of a white Christmas and she doesn't drink enough water (l. 19).
From this lifestyle, you can assume that she got used to not care of herself because of her foster families who gave her everytime not much (cf. ll. 14ff.).
Furthermore, Helen loves forehead kisses (l. 19) because she loves near and close relationships.
She wants to get love which also gets obvious when she sits close to Pearl and rubbs her forehead againsagainst Pearl's arm (ll. 41f.).
You can also conclude that she wants to get love which she never got.
This is also an evident for her sadness and loneliness.
In addition to, Helen wants to sleep forever (l. 20).
Due to her wish you can assume that her life makes no sense and she is depressive.
Helen is here also described as sad.

Because of Leo's description (cf. ll. 20ff.) and his attitude to accept Helen's chatter because there was no way to follow her (l. 22) the narrator describes Helen as a confusing and strange character who lives in her own world.
It is too hard for her to live this kind of life.
The fact that she has seventeen phones (l. 26) because every foster home she goes to, they give her a phone and tell to keep in touch (l. 27) shows that she was at 17 foster families in age of eight.
When Pearl asks her for what she will do to the phones (cf. l. 31) she answers that she callcalls the people in her family and of course her friends Lulu, Gina and Romey (ll. 32f.).
It also highlights the importance of the people in her foster families although they was very unkind to her.
That is why Helen is described also as a naive character.
She also could be angry with them and do not call them but she does.
Calling her friends emphasizeemphasizes that she has social contacts and is not very lonely as it gets obvious through her situation but it does not really change of her sadness and loneliness.
She askasks them only questions like do you like cats? (l. 34) but not more.
So this shows that their relationship is not very close it is rather a relationship in distance.

The fact that Helen needs close relationship and love from anyone also gets obvious at the end when she sits close to Pearl and rubbs her forehead againsagainst her arm (cf. ll. 41f.) and the way how Helen tells Pearl that she smells like bug-off (l. 42) is like a children's language.
You can assume that she is childish and is still very young.
She has not a knowledge as an adult which also underlines that she has a terrible and hard life.
To come to a conclusion, Helen is a small and young girl who had not never a real family.
She is a very sad, naive, loyal and lonely person who is looking at getting love from anyone.
